title: Wavestar - Out Of Time (New Age 1997 - lossless)
description:
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                              General Information
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Artist...............: Wavestar
Album................: Out Of time
Year.................: 1997
Genre................: New Age
Label................: Groove Unlimited (New Age)
Runtime..............: 68:01
Number of Songs......: 12
Cover(s) Included....: Yes (Front, Back & CD)
Audio Format.........: Lossless
Ripper...............: Exact Audio Copy 0.95 beta 4
Encoder..............: Monkeysaudio 3.99
Source...............: CD


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                                 Release Notes
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Wavestar - Out Of Time (1997)
 
01 - Messiah (2:20)
02 - Early Voyages (6:53)
03 - Early Rain (6:28)
04 - Doom (2:14)
05 - Sea (2:48)
06 - Acrotramp (backing) (6:57)
07 - Cleopatra&#039;s Barge (6:45)
08 - Crystal Ashes (11:00)
09 - Theme (5:14)
10 - Turkish Bizarre (6:18)
11 - Acrotramp &#039;86 (8:44)
12 - Messiah (Remix) (2:16)

----------------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Not a re-union, but the next best thing. John Dyson has gathered together various unreleased Wavestar pieces, some of which were destined for the follow-up to &#039;Moonwind&#039;, and released them on what is effectively a Wavestar retrospective. As John says himself in the sleevenotes "...I think I&#039;ve forgotten most of the reasons why they were left to moulder. Therefore there is no reason why you shouldn&#039;t hear them." The journey begins with &#039;Messiah&#039;, recorded in early &#039;88 and was perhaps destined to be the opener of the new album. It certainly has that "setting out" feeling and the 2:18 length suggest it may have been spliced with something else. &#039;Early Voyages&#039; is an early version of &#039;Voyager&#039; from the &#039;Moonwind&#039; album. Same feel and atmosphere though the sequencing is only suggested, this being largely a sketch of the opening section. &#039;Early Rain&#039; will be familiar to owners of &#039;Different Values&#039; as the track &#039;Through the Rain&#039; was based on this. John himself admits he prefers this version because of the sequencing and I agree. &#039;Doom&#039; is dominated by dark percussives and by Wavestar&#039;s standards is a weird interlude. &#039;Sea&#039; really was an adhoc number, quickly conceived and never revisited but sounding fresh and somehow newborn. Two different versions of &#039;Acrotramp&#039; feature on the album, and with the first its your chance to add the lead-line. After reworking the piece with the TR707 drum machine they never got round to re-laying the theme, so it&#039;s Wavestar Karaoke time! Up to now the album has been largely as advertised, a collection of interesting sketches and early versions. However, with the next 2 tracks things start to get seriously interesting. &#039;Cleopatra&#039;s Barge&#039; opens with classic Wavestar sequencing, constantly ebbing and flowing, supplemented by string synth refrains. It&#039;s a mesmeric piece which should have fans smiling with nostalgic pleasure. However, once they&#039;ve heard &#039;Crystal Ashes&#039; they should be jumping for joy. Described by John as &#039;...the one track we did finish for the proposed album&#039; this piece underlines what a masterpiece that was destined to be. Chunky analog sequencing, beautiful chord changes and succulent themes combine to perfection. Apparently it was aired at the &#039;86 Electronica and though John confesses to having made a complete "balls-up" of it he&#039;s delighted to present it here as it should have sounded! &#039;Theme&#039; is a bright optimistic affair to match the athletics festival it was written for. Superficially it can sound lightweight but the sequencing especially must have taken some time to put together. &#039;Turkish Bizarre&#039; is a suitably atmospheric piece laden with eastern promise. A delightful reedy synth theme is backed by complex percussive sequencing. &#039;Acrotramp 86&#039; is actually a very different piece to the original and is in no way inferior. It&#039;s another beautifully crafted outing with pulsing rhythms and a whimsical lead. A remix of &#039;Messiah&#039; ends the album - "more in time than out of time" are John&#039;s concluding comments, hinting at the double edged origins of the album title. John as ever is doing himself an injustice. There&#039;s plenty to please on this album with &#039;Crystal Ashes&#039; alone destined to become an all time New Age classic alongside &#039;Time Node&#039; and &#039;Voyager&#039;.
--------------------------------------------------------
An almost invaluable release by the historic New Age EM British duo John Dyson & David Ward Hunt containing a masterful blend of atmospheric and comic oriented music from days gone by. Great post CD-production & mastering done by Ron Boots. The bestseller-CD from Klemdag 1997!
The music is from the "Moonwind" period and all music is previously unreleased.
